data.text: (THREAD) The most serious risk to the economy at the start of the pandemic would have been for us to have done nothing, President @Lagarde tells @LaProvence. We will maintain our measures until we judge that the coronavirus crisis phase is over https://t.co/FpTwhk3lNO 1/3 https://t.co/l8A37Aigrn

Timely and orderly macroeconomic climate policies to tackle climate related risks can help to reduce the risks to financial stability, particularly in carbon intensive sectors. Read our report https://t.co/1mH0xhOL9O 4/4

Financial exposures to transition risks resulting from financial market repricing are concentrated in the manufacturing, electricity, transportation and construction sectors. They also vary within them depending on firms’ emission efficiency 3/4

Financial exposures to physical risks are concentrated regionally. River floods will be the most economically significant widespread climate risk driver in the European Union in the years ahead. Other sources of physical risks are wildfires, heat, or water scarcity 2/4

(THREAD) Climate-related risks to financial stability are concentrated in certain regions, sectors and firms. Our joint report with the @ESRBofficial shows that an effective and timely transition to a low-carbon economy is needed to limit their impact https://t.co/6pcVfaviNl 1/4 https://t.co/dVezshm1y1

Introductory statement by Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria at today’s hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/3zVrFBdCnb https://t.co/Tuvn95y033

Watch live at 10:00 CET: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow the live webcast here https://t.co/8JIOTPIX9i https://t.co/GqMzRAiPID

Tune in tomorrow at 10:00 CET to watch Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN. Watch live at https://t.co/8JIOTPIX9i https://t.co/hdgEpPNnHy
Eurosystem contribution to the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) consultation on the framework for EU money market funds https://t.co/FAddxnbawb
Lagarde: The pandemic has shown that economic trends can move far quicker than people think – let’s take this opportunity to show that institutions in Europe can do the same 3/3

Lagarde: 3⃣ reasons for a green CMU:

1. Capital markets are well-suited to financing of future-oriented sectors like green and digital
2. Europe already has a headstart as the home of green capital markets
3. We have the potential to make rapid progress

2/3

(THREAD) In a speech at the Brussels Economic Forum, President @Lagarde says that the European post-pandemic plan needs a green capital markets union (CMU) to go alongside Next Generation EU

https://t.co/AHjoKrwNTJ

1/3 https://t.co/fG89vpfdaZ

The digital euro would be for all Europeans to use, from everywhere to everybody and everywhere they want to send the money in the euro area. It would be risk-free and simply technological progress, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @EBFeu’s online event. https://t.co/ByWGav9SMS

EU banking rules sometimes give options to supervisors. Share your views on our revised policies. The revisions are due to recent legal changes and ensure transparency, consistency and a level playing field.
The consultation is open until 23 August 2021 
https://t.co/oUzcvgRYu5 https://t.co/winXf8QAwB

Banks have fulfilled their vital role of lending to the real economy during the pandemic, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. That role remains just as important now as the recovery gathers pace https://t.co/Azxu80kdR5 https://t.co/r8jQs7A0xO

Panetta: Next Generation EU, flexible monetary policy, monetary-fiscal interactions – all of these innovations are helping our monetary union to function better. We now have an opportunity to build on them and permanently lift euro area growth to higher levels 4/4

Panetta: We should recognise that what was seen as unconventional in the past is now conventional. In particular, we should strive to retain the unconventional flexibility that has served us well during the pandemic 3/4

Panetta: If we are seen as determined to achieve 2% inflation without undue delay and enable monetary-fiscal interactions, rising inflation expectations will make our task easier. Otherwise, we will end up spending more, not less, and we may not exit the liquidity trap 2/4

We should not be afraid of monetary and fiscal policies working together, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. It has the potential to bring us back sustainably to our inflation aim and to an economy operating at full capacity https://t.co/6Ryqy9O34q 1/4 https://t.co/Qe21lEoRAo

Have measures aimed at limiting banks’ dividend payouts and share buy-backs helped them to keep lending and absorb losses? What could be the longer-term impact of this and what are the drawbacks? Find out in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/32buiA3rFo https://t.co/xdT9F8oPZJ
Changes to the Eurosystem’s loan-level data requirements https://t.co/cwi27FGn9q
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/mX4wLUqh4p
ECB takes over supervision of systemic investment firms https://t.co/rS0hD8MSxe
Guest lecture Isabel Schnabel: The ECB’s policy response to the COVID-19 pandemic https://t.co/tZEgIkLvF9
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in May? How do they compare with April’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/5ggC1nlFk0 https://t.co/CuiXGfiNLj

Register now and watch live at 17:30 CET today: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel speaks about our policy response to the coronavirus crisis in a guest lecture at the @UCYOfficial https://t.co/fV5QgOxAVj https://t.co/1C62RPfPZC https://t.co/4eyfaf3kQ8
ECB publishes consolidated banking data for end-December 2020 https://t.co/TtPG6eXDLr
The European Commission, ECB Banking Supervision, EBA and ESMA encourage market participants to cease all LIBOR settings https://t.co/AnlvLXbcN2

Deficits in euro area Member States are expected to remain high in coming years. Public investment supports recovery from the pandemic, but the growth-friendliness of public finances must be improved, especially in high-debt countries https://t.co/ibrNxyvXhp #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/XrcXA0MMrp

Euro area manufacturers in areas such as computers, electronics and cars are facing bottlenecks due to a global shortage of semiconductors. Despite planned investments in production capacity, the problem is expected to persist for a while https://t.co/BZuMpK2DG0 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/VAzbK24jTP

The level of excess liquidity in the euro area hit a record high due to the combined effect of PEPP purchases and TLTRO allotments. Meanwhile, demand for liquidity from regular refinancing operations fell to a record low. Read more https://t.co/SyquwaRVSF #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/96IobZ4lj1
The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary analysis which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/Q99lVVBBDd https://t.co/74dSxrGU0q

Watch live tomorrow at 13:40 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta will talk about a digital euro at the @EBFeu online event. Register now and tune in! https://t.co/XNgQ9vWT6R https://t.co/htVvgTGyfK

Two-thirds of interviewed large firms and SMEs used at least one government support measure during the coronavirus pandemic. The vast majority found this to be vital in covering their immediate and medium-term costs. Read more https://t.co/rRDV4BA5me #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/pGsD91GBpj

The coronavirus crisis hit the euro area labour market hard, with different impacts on different sectors, despite job retention schemes. Some sector-specific nuances across genders are also visible. Read more https://t.co/qc83AH17qS #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/l94slp2ich

If policy support for non-viable companies, so-called zombie firms, goes on for too long, this can become an issue for financial stability, says our expert Tamarah Shakir on the #TheECBPodcast with host @KatieRanger_. Tune in to find out more https://t.co/zZTr6KktgH https://t.co/I7IZ8B9LsH

Congratulations to the nine finalist teams of the 2021 #EUDatathon, and to all the participants for their great proposals! The winner will be announced during the #EUOpenDataDays on 25 November, where the finalists will present the apps they are developing https://t.co/UoPkz3jdyL https://t.co/4SHBSLkgac

Watch live from 16:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses his recent paper on the resilience of the euro at the Athens University of Economics and Business (@AUEB)

https://t.co/mwvf3JWVPJ https://t.co/CfEPgfdEOz

In recent decades inflation rates across advanced economies have displayed a synchronised decline. Empirical evidence shows that globalisation has not been a major driver, so a slowdown in globalisation would do little to boost inflation https://t.co/hudhS9rRxC #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/Sfsl7iRBwm

Lagarde: We gathered essential input for our strategy review from civil society organisations and citizens to analysts and politicians. I greatly appreciate the insightful contributions from the @Europarl_EN throughout the process.

Lagarde: As the recovery gathers pace, we need to remain vigilant and ensure that policy support continues to provide a bridge over the pandemic and well into the recovery. The European approach adopted during this crisis is a great achievement and should be strengthened further.
Lagarde: Negative interest rates have often been criticised because of their potential side effects. Our assessment continues to be positive as the benefits continue to outweigh the costs.

Lagarde: Our measures have proven effective in preserving favourable financing conditions for all sectors of the economy. This is essential for supporting a sustained economic recovery and for safeguarding price stability.

Lagarde: Inflation has picked up over recent months in the euro area, largely owing to temporary factors, including strong increases in energy prices. Headline inflation is likely to increase further towards the autumn, continuing to reflect temporary factors.

Lagarde: The outlook for the euro area economy is brightening as the pandemic situation improves, the vaccination campaigns progress, and confidence begins to rise. We expect economic activity to accelerate as of this quarter.
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Philippe Lamberts, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/oxqgD8UXIn
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/Mn8CubgMhF

Live now: President @Lagarde speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow here https://t.co/PJt9yWLujf @EP_Economics https://t.co/wNGDf1zFYO

It is important to look below the surface to detect any potential turbulences, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. There are many positive developments, yet there are also some warning lights that call for caution https://t.co/m3VSx83TE1 https://t.co/S8v2OWlOyV
Working Paper: Rational inattention - A review https://t.co/TbiasPL5DQ
Working Paper: Voting right rotation, behavior of committee members and financial market reactions - Evidence  from the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee https://t.co/Fr0nVOXXIj

The euro area current account surplus shrank slightly in 2020, to 2.2% of GDP. One of the largest coronavirus-related impacts was the sharp reduction in the services surplus due to travel restrictions during the pandemic. Read more https://t.co/RHo4Xs6F54 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/aNi7W1YnfI
Euro area pension fund statistics (Q1 2021) https://t.co/WIUNRiWVja
Economic Bulletin Box: Euro area house price developments during the COVID-19 pandemic https://t.co/30TPHhQAny
Tune in at 16:15 CET to watch President Christine @Lagarde speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN https://t.co/PJt9yWLujf @EP_Economics https://t.co/A7XgzexpT8

The Governing Council met this weekend for its annual retreat, which focused on advancing the discussions of the monetary policy strategy review. It was its first in-person meeting since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic 
https://t.co/oLRfwgYBjT https://t.co/Hn5vdUHmAA

Panetta: The experimentation done so far gives us a preliminary sense of the pros and cons of different technologies. If the Governing Council gives us the green light in July we will start a formal investigation phase focusing on the design of a digital euro 3/3

Panetta: Central banks are better placed to protect privacy in digital payments: we have no commercial interest in user data and we could ensure that nobody in the payment chain has access to all the information. For small amounts, we could allow anonymous payments 2/3

(THREAD) A digital euro would be a powerful push for digitalisation, offering a safe, costless means of payment and allowing intermediaries to provide services with “digital euro inside”, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta to the @FinancialTimes https://t.co/YSP4Mn7ehr 1/3 https://t.co/r6LPYiiT3v
Interview Fabio Panetta with Financial Times https://t.co/YSP4Mn7ehr

As governments begin to phase out policy support measures for the economy, we need to be wary of the risks ahead, says our financial stability expert @JohnPCFell. Tune into the #TheECBPodcast with our host @KatieRanger_ to find out more https://t.co/zZTr6KktgH https://t.co/8wQRiWdHeZ

How do we make sure that your payments remain safe and reliable, while also keeping up with the latest payment trends and technologies? We discussed these topics with civil society representatives this week. Watch the full event here https://t.co/705IqMRlME

Exceptional circumstances persist. We will therefore allow euro area banks to exclude central bank exposures from their leverage ratios until March 2022. However, only new exposures since the beginning of the pandemic lead to leverage ratio relief https://t.co/TOi9IhYLKA https://t.co/LQYAizfvqS
Working Paper: Do macroprudential measures increase inequality? Evidence from the euro area household survey https://t.co/Wbb3e6ASpv
Working Paper: No country is an island - International cooperation and climate change https://t.co/msybYgll2M
Euro area monthly balance of payments (April 2021) https://t.co/YkNrmix7Ms
You can also watch the full interview here https://t.co/Ljv4MWRx7g

Monetary policy doesn’t turn on a dime, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @Bloomberg TV. Our focus is on medium-term inflation. He also discusses why talking about ending the PEPP is premature and why not to compare monetary policy in the US and Europe https://t.co/FCSMemqx3W https://t.co/rIXXAA67fT

Watch live at 8:30 CET today: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane answers questions on monetary policy, inflation and the economic recovery by @pgordon66 in an interview with @BloombergTV https://t.co/eFTyItzWal https://t.co/x7Ge6q33QN

What does financial stability have to do with cycling and zombies? How has the third wave of the pandemic affected the financial system? What risks lie ahead? Tune in to #TheECBPodcast with our experts Tamarah Shakir, @JohnPCFell and our host @KatieRanger_ https://t.co/zZTr6KktgH https://t.co/ejqwmBT4UW

Most banks do not yet meet our expectations on managing and disclosing climate risks, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson. Progress is possible and needed. Climate data are not perfect yet, but banks can use existing tools to address the risks https://t.co/A39Pu8mhPi https://t.co/pNjephJyZO

The ultimate impact of the pandemic on non-performing loans once public support measures are completely lifted is uncertain, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. Banks must recognise credit deterioration as swiftly and accurately as possible https://t.co/yu2aoz5kC3 https://t.co/VZT8mEWWag

We want to protect the role of cash as a means of payment and a store of value, even if we issue a digital euro, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @Bundesbank. That’s also why we adopted the Eurosystem’s Cash 2030 Strategy. Read more https://t.co/GEGsoCHL4H https://t.co/WQlaqNURbu

Panetta: During the crisis people used cash to manage uncertainty: they cut spending and held more physical money. Cash also allows people to make payments at no cost, which in particular benefits individuals with lower income or who don’t have a bank account 2/2 https://t.co/5iQE98XBom

Faster digitalisation does not mean the end for cash, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @Bundesbank. Cash plays a crucial role in the euro area and there is demand for it. Read the speech https://t.co/WFqPprlU38 1/2 https://t.co/NPGmfCnUcN

The rate at which euro area households saved almost doubled in 2020 in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Explore how households’ savings developed in the euro area in our latest insight, available in 23 languages https://t.co/cbfbieJqLd https://t.co/yFzADtDB8U

Register now and watch live from 12:00 CET: Andrea Enria talks about the state of the European banking sector and its supervision at @AFME_EU/@OMFIF conference https://t.co/Ud7YJrqp54 https://t.co/2ZdTwrkR5z

McCaul and @FrankElderson: The goal is clear: that our institution, the banks that we supervise and financial institutions at large become more effective and safer, and that they are a true reflection of the population that they ultimately serve – the people of Europe 4/4

McCaul and @FrankElderson: In cooperation with the national competent authorities, we will also roll out other medium and long-term supervisory measures aimed at fostering diversity within the boards of European banks 3/4

McCaul and @FrankElderson: As part of our fit and proper assessments we at the ECB will look closely at the gender diversity of banks’ boards in addition to assessing the adequacy of their collective knowledge, skills and experience 2/4

(Thread) Diversity in leadership is crucial for effective governance, write Vice-Chair @FrankElderson and Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul in #TheSupervisionBlog. It fosters independence of opinions and an openness to challenge decisions https://t.co/FfAbjR3uyK 1/4 https://t.co/x0L5da49X0

Watch live now: @DianaUrge from @CEU and Nobel laureate Michael Spence from @Stanford discuss climate change, climate policies and sustainable growth in a panel moderated by @MESandbu at our joint symposium with @cepr_org  and @EBRD https://t.co/Gl3dofmVek https://t.co/SfjrytXIX6

We at the ECB can act as a catalyst to accelerate the transition to a carbon-neutral economy in line with our mandate, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Replacing market neutrality by market efficiency would acknowledge climate externalities https://t.co/UQj2xKpToj https://t.co/V9EoqVhPK5

Watch live today at 15:00 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel talks about how we at the ECB can contribute to the global fight against climate change within our mandate, in her welcome speech at our joint symposium with @cepr_org and @EBRD https://t.co/bjtkqSLtkU https://t.co/EHcIAG4yr9

Lagarde on #NextGenerationEU: we need to make sure it goes towards projects that enhance growth and structural reforms. It’s a big challenge and one that can really transform the future of Europe. I think all governments know that https://t.co/CV5cVVK230 5/5

Lagarde on multilateralism: it’s a relief to see this impetus, momentum, determination to come together as we have witnessed in the last six months. Before there were a few years of difficult multilateralism, but now it’s clearly back 4/5

Lagarde on climate change: I hope that when we complete the strategy review, climate change will have a space. We are riveted to our price stability objective and we are the custodian of the euro, but we have to be attentive to the big developments around us too 3/5

Lagarde on the end of the PEPP: we see the euro area economy being back to the pre-COVID-19 level during Q1 2022. Our projection, and the design of the PEPP, seems to be heading in the right direction, but it is far too early to debate issues such as when it will end 2/5

(THREAD) We need to anchor the recovery from the pandemic, President @Lagarde tells @PoliticoEurope’s @JohannaTreeck and @florianeder. The recovery has started but it needs to be firm, solid and sustainable before we can reduce support to the economy https://t.co/CV5cVVK230 1/5 https://t.co/iETNfYcvwr

Tomorrow at 16:45 CET we will be livestreaming a panel on “Climate change, climate policies and sustainable growth” with @DianaUrge and Michael Spence, moderated by @MESandbu as part of our Symposium with @cepr_org and @EBRD – watch live here https://t.co/C34qYWkm8d https://t.co/bjTepSfCvd

Tomorrow at 15:00 CET we will stream a speech by @Isabel_Schnabel about how we at the ECB can contribute to the global fight against climate change within our mandate, as part of our Symposium on climate change with @cepr_org and @EBRD – watch live here https://t.co/C34qYWkm8d https://t.co/mk1uz55TWX

The European Football Championship is kicking off at last ⚽️
We are getting ready to cheer for all 🇪🇺 teams participating in #EURO2020. 
May the best team win! https://t.co/4navqPOw3N

By clarifying our approach to consolidation among banks, we hope to foster mergers that generate synergies, improve cost efficiency and result in well-capitalised and resilient banks, says Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo https://t.co/gJkflY3Rpv https://t.co/hR4MxRsdzo
Watch again: President @Lagarde on the effects of our monetary policy measures https://t.co/IyrrCjNRzN
Watch again: President @Lagarde on economic scarring left by the pandemic https://t.co/HlS1MK9Pfs

Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/LGGK0747P9 https://t.co/ncn0S670e4

Projection charts and tables https://t.co/xmzCzm9U7i https://t.co/bPGZSFJNGc
